Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties are exempt from notifying the Secretary and reporting requirements. The amendments take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. The amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These organizations are defined as those solely focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices. The amendment exempts State or local political organizations focused on influencing the selection of individuals for public offices from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These organizations must report as required by State law. The amendment exempts State or local political organizations from reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, but they must still report as required by State law. This includes information on expenditures, contributions, and the individuals involved. The amendment exempts State or local political organizations from certain reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. They must still report as required by State law, including details on expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved. State law differences are disregarded in meeting the reporting requirements. The curr_chunk provides details on the information required to be reported by individuals and organizations, including contributions, occupations, expenditures, purposes, and dates. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which an organization can still be considered a qualified State or local political organization despite making minor errors in complying with reporting and inspection requirements. It also specifies that a federal candidate or office holder cannot be part of such an organization if they control or significantly participate in its activities or solicit contributions. The amendments made by this section specify that a federal candidate or office holder cannot be part of a qualified State or local political organization if they control or participate in its activities, solicit contributions, or direct disbursements. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization Taxable Income. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Disclosure by the secretary and public inspection amended. Information Returns amended for political organizations. The section amends information returns required for political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, or $100,000 for qualified State or local political organizations. Annual returns must be filed with necessary information for section 527 compliance. The section amends information returns for political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, requiring annual filings with necessary information for section 527 compliance. Mandatory exceptions from filing apply to specific types of organizations. The section amends information returns for political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, requiring annual filings with necessary information for section 527 compliance. Specific types of organizations are exempt from filing, and the Secretary has discretionary authority to waive filing requirements if deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The Secretary has the discretion to exempt organizations from filing information returns if it is deemed unnecessary for tax administration. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to Public Law 106-230. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the impact of amendments made by this Act and the interaction of reporting requirements under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code and the Federal Election Campaign Act. Information on these requirements will be included in guidance issued to the public. Additionally, there is a provision for waiver of filing amounts. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000.

SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income whether or not segregated.
(b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Amounts imposed under section 527(j) shall be assessed and collected like penalties under section 6652(c).
(c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Electronic filings are sufficient under section 527(i)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
(d) Application of Fraud Penalty.--Section 7207 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies to fraudulent returns and statements. (e) Contents and Filing of Report.-- Section 527(j)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include additional details in the report contents and require electronic filing. The amendment requires electronic filing of reports for organizations with significant contributions or expenditures, making them available for public inspection online within 48 hours. The Secretary must make notices and reports available to the public online within 48 hours of filing. The database must be searchable by various items such as names, states, contributors, and time periods. The database of organizations must include entities, contributors, employers, recipients, contribution/expenditure ranges, and time periods. Notices must indicate if an organization seeks exemption from certain requirements. Any material changes in information must be promptly notified. The timing of notice for material changes in information required for tax exemption must be given within 30 days of the change, failure to do so may result in adjustments to income and deductions. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 specifies that in case of a failure related to a material change, income and deductions will only be considered from the date of the change until notice is given. Effective dates for the amendments vary depending on the subsection, with some applying to failures occurring after the enactment of the Act and others applying to reports and notices filed after specific dates. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 have specific effective dates depending on the subsection. Subsection (d) applies to reports and notices filed after the enactment of the Act, subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to filings more than 30 days after the enactment, subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports filed after June 30, 2003, and subsection (g) applies to material changes after the enactment date with a transition rule for changes within 30 days. During the 30-day period after the enactment of this Act, a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is not required to be filed before 30 days after a material change or 45 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
